awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Analysis of Water Waves and Other Fluid Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite their ubiquity and importance in physics and engineering, water waves remain very difficult to analyze or to predict, largely because of the presence of the unknown, time-varying fluid domain and the nonlinear way the spatiotemporal patterns affect the transport of energy and fluid particles. While many analytical tools currently exist for studying water waves of small amplitude, this project focuses on developing new machinery to construct large-amplitude waves and to investigate their ability to persist under small perturbations. Another objective of this project is to understand how energy evolves in response to the interaction between a fluid and a solid. Results from this project will advance the mathematical theory of water waves and contribute to understanding of other mathematical models in fluid mechanics and other related branches of applied science and engineering. This research also involves training and collaboration with graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.

This project will develop a rigorous study of some nonlinear partial differential equations arising from water waves and other fluid models, extending some of the analytic techniques to related contexts, and integrating the research to the education of undergraduate and graduate students. Specifically, the proposed research addresses three separate directions regarding the existence and qualitative properties of the solutions to the water wave problem as well as other physically significant systems: (1) using a novel global bifurcation theoretic machinery to construct large-amplitude front-type  solutions  and  solitary  wave solutions to a two-phase fluid system in a channel, and extend this global theory to handle traveling waves that evolve according to more general symmetry groups; (2) proving the spectral stability of solitary waves to some long-wave water wave  model  which  are  indefinite energy saddles; (3) establishing  exact  energy equality for a fluid-interaction model and deriving sufficient conditions for the weak inviscid limit of Navier-Stokes solutions in domains with boundary.  The main ingredients and techniques involved in the study include methods from elliptic partial differential equations,  bifurcation and degree theory and stability analysis, together with  energy estimates and Fourier analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project aims at developing a rigorous study of some nonlinear PDEs arising from water waves and other fluid models, and extending some of the analytic techniques to related contexts. Specific topics investigated include existence and stability of traveling waves, structural stability of compressible elastic vortex sheets, non-uniqueness of isentropic Euler system, and inviscid limits. In total, this project has produced 16 papers, which has presented a substantial contribution to the field. Many of these results were obtained through the development of new systematic tools that will drive future research. Some major findings include the following.  

1. Existence of traveling waves in unbounded cylinders.

We developed a general theory for constructing large front-type solutions to elliptic PDEs set on unbounded domains.  Problems of this form can be found in many physical contexts, including nonlinear elasticity, biology, and hydrodynamics. As one of the applications, our machinery was used to construct large-amplitude internal hydrodynamic bores of elevation and depression. Existence of small amplitude bores has been extensively studied in the literature, but this is first rigorous work that pushes into the non-perturbative regime. Of special significance is that, in the limit along the curve of elevation bores, the interfaces either overturn or become singular in that the flow in both layers degenerates at a single point on the boundary. Following the the curve of depression bores to its extreme, the interface either overturns or contacts the upper wall. Both possibilities are well-connected to longstanding open problems in water waves.

2. Stability of traveling waves.

We have studied the nonlinear stability of traveling waves for both the full water wave problem and some asymptotic model equations. We were able to characterize the stability of capillary-gravity internal waves in a channel. We proved the (conditional) orbital stability in the natural energy space for small-amplitude solitary waves in the strong surface tension regime. With near-critical surface tension, moreover, it was shown that the stability/instability is determined by consideration of a far simpler dispersive model equation. We also made several discoveries regarding the stability of solitary waves exhibiting corner-type singularities. We proved, using a Lyapunov function approach combined with a delicate use of the conserved quantities, the orbital stability of the peaked waves in the natural energy space. Moreover by exploiting the localization structure of the energy we were able to establish a rigidity property, which allows one to obtain asymptotic stability. 

3. Stability of compressible elastic vortex sheets.

Vortex sheets are interfaces between two flows passing along each other. They arise in a broad range of physical problems in fluid mechanics, aerodynamics, oceanography and astrophysical plasma. For ideal fluids or fluids at high Reynolds number, vortex sheets tend to be unstable. However for complex fluids, the interaction between difference flow phases may result in certain stabilization of the vortex sheets. We considered a two-dimensional inviscid solid-liquid two-phase flow and proved the nonlinear stability and local existence of compressible elastic vortex sheets in the usual Sobolev spaces. 

4. Convex integration for compressible Euler systems.

The compressible Euler model is one of the most important models in the theory of hyperbolic conservation laws. One outstanding problem is the uniqueness/non-uniqueness of weak solutions. We investigated the non-uniqueness of weak solutions to the compressible isentropic gas dynamics system. By employing the convex integration procedure developed by De Lellis-Sz\'ekelyhidi, we proved that for any initial datum belonging to a dense subset of the energy space, there exist infinitely many global-in-time admissible weak solutions to the isentropic Euler system.

5. Inviscid limits.

The nature of the inviscid limit from the Navier-Stokes equations to Euler equations is a fundamental problem in the study of fluid dynamics. For flows in bounded domains, establishing the vanishing viscosity limit in the energy space, even in the presence of a strong Euler solution, remains widely open. Therefore it is natural to consider the weak Euler solutions for the vanishing viscosity limit. We proved that the well-known Kato’s criterion holds for the H\"older continuous solutions with the regularity index arbitrarily close to Onsager’s critical exponent.

 

Broader Impacts:

The results of this award were disseminated to the community through 35 invited talks at domestic and international research institutes. Three workshops on fluid dynamics and nonlinear waves were co-organized by the PI during the award period.. Virtual working group meetings on topics relevant to the project are held weekly where graduate students and postdocs are participating and giving presentations. 

The award has supported the research of one PhD student of the PI who has made important contributions to the project. His work resulted in two papers, both published in high tier mathematics journals. This award also provides training opportunities for an undergraduate student, who has graduated and continued in pursuing a PhD degree.
